si9.svg svg 7761 ALTIMG MCAT 115333 115333 S2468-8231(25)00521-8 10.1016/j.mcat.2025.115333 Fig. 1 The relationship between raw materials and reaction products. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a, b) XRD patterns and (c, d) FT-IR spectra of catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of (a) SiO2 and (b) 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2, (c-e) TEM images and (f) EDS mapping of 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2. Fig 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of (a) Rh 3d for 0.2Rh/SiO2, (b) Rh 3d, and (c) W 4f for 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2. Fig 4 Fig. 5 In-situ FTIR spectra of (a) 0.2Rh/SiO2 and (b) 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Catalytic performance: (a) Effect of different Rh loadings on conversion and selectivity for x %Rh/SiO2. (b) Effect of different W loadings on conversion and selectivity for 0.2Rh-y %WOx/SiO2. (c) Recycling performance of 0.2Rh/SiO2 and 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2. (d) FT-IR spectra of 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 before and after the cyclic stability test. Reaction condition: 90 ℃, 5 MPa, 5 h, 18 mmol isobutene, 100 mg catalyst, and 600 rpm. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) XRD patterns of Al2O3 and 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3 catalyst, (b) comparison of TON between the catalysts 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3 and 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2. (c) Recyclability performance and (d) corresponding TON variations of 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3 and 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 over four reaction cycles. Reaction condition: 90 ℃, 5 MPa, 5 h, 18 mmol isobutene, 100 mg catalyst, and 600 rpm. Hydroformylation plays a crucial role in the modern chemical industry by enabling the efficient production of aldehydes, which are essential raw materials for a wide range of chemicals. In this study, we reported a pair-site 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst that demonstrated exceptional performance in isobutene hydroformylation. The catalyst achieved an isovaleraldehyde yield of 89.57 % (TON=8936) after 5 h of reaction at 90 °C and 5 MPa, and retained 85.0 % of its initial yield after four cycles. This performance was significantly superior to that of the catalyst prior to the introduction of W and proved more suitable for the hydroformylation reaction of isobutene compared to previously reported Al2O3-supported pair-site catalyst. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that W served as an electronic modulator in the catalytic system. The charge transfer from Rh to W enabled W to adsorb and convert excess CO on the Rh surface, thereby creating vacant active sites for the subsequent insertion of olefin and CO, ultimately enhancing the hydroformylation performance. The pair-site catalyst developed in this study exhibited remarkable improvements in both catalytic activity and stability, offering valuable guidance for catalyst design from an interface science perspective. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydroformylation Pair-site Isobutene Electronic regulation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The hydroformylation of isobutene is a crucial reaction in industrial chemistry, with its product, isovaleraldehyde, widely applied in food processing, pharmaceuticals, and pesticide synthesis [1–3]. Currently, homogeneous catalysts such as HRh(CO)(PPh3)3 are widely employed in this field. However, the inherent challenge of separating the products from the catalysts has become a significant limitation. Consequently, there is an urgent need to develop novel and highly efficient catalysts. In this context, Rhodium-based heterogeneous catalysts, which offer the advantage of facile separation, are emerging as a promising research focus [4]. In 1962, Heck and Breslow first proposed the mechanism of hydroformylation, which can be split into five stages [5]. (I) the adsorption of CO and H2 by the metal sites and the form of corresponding active species; (II) the coordination addition of the olefin; (III) the insertion of CO into the alkyl intermediate; (IV) the addition of hydrogen; and (V) the reductive elimination of aldehydes [6–9]. The initial adsorption of CO in step (I) and the subsequent CO insertion in step (III) both occur on the active metal, Rh. However, in step (I), CO adsorption typically occupies nearly all the active sites on the Rh surface, which hinders the subsequent reaction [10,11]. Hence, designing a catalyst that can effectively regulate CO adsorption or convert CO adsorbed on Rh to ensure the availability of active sites required for subsequent reactions is crucial for enhancing the catalytic efficiency of hydroformylation [8,9]. To tackle this challenge, researchers have explored various strategies, including incorporating a second metal on the catalyst surface to exploit its competitive interactions with Rh. Williams et al. [12] prepared a bimetallic RhCo3/SBA-15 catalyst through the wet impregnation method. With ethylene as the reactant, the C3 yield reached 50 %, approximately 3.1 times great than that of the single-metal Rh/SBA-15 catalyst. Wei et al. [13] developed a Rh-Co-P/ZnO catalyst, which compared to Rh/ZnO, significantly increased the ratio of n-capric aldehyde to isocapric aldehyde from 0.7 to 2.1. Additionally, the selectivity for linear aldehydes improved from 32.1 % to 54.9 % in decene hydroformylation. It indicated that the introduction of Co and P modified the surface electronic environment of the active metal. As demonstrated in recent studies, through the synergistic interaction between Rh and an additional metal, the catalytic performance has been improved to a certain extent. The second solution involved enhancing the interaction between Rh and the catalyst substrate, which can modify the surface electron density of Rh and further adjust its capacity for the adsorption of CO [14]. Zheng et al. [15] demonstrated that the calcination temperature significantly influenced the concentration of oxygen vacancies on CeO2, which in turn affected the electronic structure of Rh. An optimal calcination temperature favored the formation of active HRh(CO)2 species, enhancing olefin adsorption and CO insertion. Lee et al. [14] manipulated the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio to modify the surface properties of the support, thereby influencing the electron density associated with Rh. The intensity of the Rh-CO interaction diminished as the electron density of Rh increased, due to an appropriate proportion of Ce3+ and Ce4+, facilitating CO desorption and thus provided a suitable chemical environment for the subsequent insertion of CO on the alkyl intermediate. The enhancement of the interaction between the support and Rh has been shown to positively influence the activity and stability of the catalyst to some extent. However, despite these strategies, the catalytic activity of rhodium has not been fully realized due to the excessive adsorption of CO on the Rh surface. Regulating CO adsorption on the Rh surface, while simultaneously improving both catalyst activity and stability, remains a challenge that requires further investigation. Ro et al. [11] proposed an innovative pair-site strategy. In this approach, the second metal did not directly participate in the catalytic process. Instead, it acted as a metal promoter, interacting with Rh to regulate the adsorption of CO. This interaction facilitated the conversion of CO on the Rh surface to CO2, which then desorbed, freeing up active sites on Rh to provide for subsequent reactions. Tungsten, with its exceptional electrical conductivity, multiple accessible oxidation states, and strong affinity for small molecules such as CO, H2, and O2, represents a particularly attractive choice for such promotion. Li et al. [16] developed a Pt/W-SiO2 catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol into 1, 3-propanediol using standard Schlenk line techniques and impregnation. The experiments demonstrated that the greater the coordination of WOx and Pt, the stronger the adsorption of dissociated hydrogen from Pt onto WOx, facilitating the formation of the WOx-H isolated species, which in turn drove the reaction by promoting the binding of hydrogen to the terminal hydroxyl group on glycerol. γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts exhibit excellent activity in ethylene hydroformylation [11,12]. The abundant Lewis acid sites on Al2O3 promote the strong adsorption of olefinic intermediates; however, the prolonged residence time of the intermediates may also lead to a series of issues [17,18]. SiO2 possesses a high specific surface area, remarkable chemical stability, and thermal stability, making it an ideal support material with promising application potential. For instance, Liu et al. [19] 2019employed amorphous SiO₂ as the support and introduced triphenylphosphine to prepare the RhPdP/SiO₂ catalyst, achieving 90 % olefin conversion in the hydroformylation of styrene within 4 h. Huang et al. [20] developed a bimetallic catalyst by loading Rh and Co onto SiO2, which achieved a propionaldehyde productivity of 75 mol·molRh⁻¹·h⁻¹ in ethylene hydroformylation. Similarly, Wang et al. [21] fabricated a monometallic Rh/SiO2 catalyst via impregnation, achieving over 90 % conversion in the hydroformylation of pentene and hexene. Building on the analysis above and the pair-sites catalysis approach, and considering the differences in the interactions between various supports and active metals, in this work, amorphous SiO2, which is inexpensive and readily available, was chosen as the support to prepare the Rh-WOx/SiO2 catalyst. We systematically investigated the effects of Rh and W loadings on the catalytic performance, and compared with Rh-WOx/Al2O3 in isobutene hydroformylation. Characterization of microstructure of the catalyst was performed using XRD, FTIR, SEM, TEM, and in-situ FTIR. DFT calculations were utilized to clarify the reaction mechanism. This study offers important guidance for designing and developing catalysts for the hydroformylation of isobutene into isovaleraldehyde. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were sourced from commercial suppliers and used as received without additional purification. Silicon dioxide (SiO2, ≥99.5 %), n-hexane (GC grade), and ammonium metatungstate (AMT, ≥99.5 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin. Toluene(AR grade) was obtained from Sinopharm Group, isobutene from Wuhan Isotope, and syngas (H2 : CO = 1 : 1) from Nanjing Special Gas Plant. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of WOx/SiO2 WOx/SiO2 were prepared via a conventional impregnation method. Typically, 0.5 g of silicon dioxide was added to 20 mL of deionized water and impregnated with the desired amount of an aqueous (NH4)6H2W12O40·4H2O solution. The mixture was stirred continuously for 12 h. After stirring, the samples were collected, washed three times with deionized water, and dried in a vacuum oven for 48 h. The dried samples were heated at a rate of 2 °C·min-1 to 600 °C and maintained at 600 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace and then cooled naturally to room temperature. The resulting white powders were labeled as y %WOx/SiO2, where y (y = 0.4, 0.8, 1.2, 1.6, and 2.0) represents the mass loading of W. The specific amounts of additives for (NH4)6H2W12O40·4H2O solution were listed in Table S1, and the calculation method was shown below: (1) W % = m w m w + m support From the above formula to calculate the value of mw, it can be deduced that: (2) V ( N H 4 ) 6 H 2 W 12 O 40 · 4 H 2 O = m w ÷ 12 × M W M ( N H 4 ) 6 H 2 W 12 O 40 · 4 H 2 O ÷ C ( N H 4 ) 6 H 2 W 12 O 40 · 4 H 2 O × 1000 m: the mass of the metal, mg. M: the molar mass of the chemical molecular, mg/mmol. C: concentration of the solution, mg/mL. V: the addition amount of (NH4)6H2W12O40·4H2O aqueous solution, μL. 2.2.2 Preparation of Rh-WOX/SiO2 The synthesis of Rh-WOx/SiO2 followed a similar procedure to that of WOx/SiO2. First, 0.3 g of y %WOx/SiO2 was added to 20 mL of deionized water and impregnated with an appropriate amount of an aqueous RhCl3·3H2O solution. The mixture was stirred for 12 h, after which the samples were collected, washed three times with deionized water, and dried in a vacuum oven for 48 h. The dried samples were calcinated at a rate of 2 °C·min-1 to 400 °C and maintained at 400 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace and then cooled to room temperature naturally. The final grey-white powders were labeled as x %Rh-y %WOx/SiO2, where x (x = 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, 0.25, and 0.3) represents the mass loading of Rh. The specific amounts of additives for RhCl3·3H2O were listed in Table S2, and the calculation method was shown below: (3) Rh % = m Rh m Rh + m support From the above formula to calculate the value of mRh, it can be deduced that: (4) V RhC l 3 · 3 H 2 O = m Rh ÷ M Rh M RhC l 3 · 3 H 2 O ÷ C RhC l 3 · 3 H 2 O × 1000 m: the mass of the metal, mg. M: the molar mass of the chemical molecular, mg/mmol. C: concentration of the solution, mg/mL. V: the addition amount of RhCl3·3H2O aqueous solution, μL. 2.2.3 Preparation of 0.7 %WOx/Al2O3 The 0.2 %Rh-0.7 %WOx/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared following the procedure reported in the literature [11]. For the preparation of 0.7 %WOx/Al2O3, 0.5 g of γ-Al2O3 was dispersed to 20 mL of deionized water and impregnated with 470 μL aqueous (NH4)6H2W12O40·4H2O solution of 10 mg/mL. The mixture was stirred continuously for 12 h. After stirring, the samples were collected, washed three times with deionized water, and dried in a vacuum oven for 48 h. The dried samples were heated in a muffle furnace at a rate of 2 °C·min-1 to 500 °C and maintained at 500 °C for 4 h and then cooled to room temperature naturally. White powders were obtained and labeled as 0.7 %WOx/Al2O3. 2.2.4 Preparation of 0.2 %Rh-0.7 %WOx/Al2O3 For the preparation of 0.2 %Rh-0.7 %WOx/Al2O3, 0.3 g of 0.7 %WOx/Al2O3 was added to 20 mL of deionized water and impregnated with 154 μL aqueous solution of RhCl3·3H2O of 10 mg/mL. The mixture was stirred for 12 h, after which the samples were collected, washed with deionized water three times, and dried in a vacuum oven for 48 h. The dried samples were heated at a rate of 2 °C·min-1 to 350 °C and maintained at 350 °C for 4 h and cooled to room temperature naturally. The final obtained grey-white powders were labeled as 0.2 %Rh-0.7 %WOx/Al2O3. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement The hydroformylation of isobutene was carried out in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with the magnetic stirrer, thermocouple, and pressure gauge. Typically, 100 mg of catalyst and 15 mL of toluene (serving as the solvent) were added to the autoclave. The autoclave was then sealed and purged three times with syngas (H2 : CO = 1 : 1) at 2 MPa to remove any residual air. Subsequently, 1 g of isobutene (18 mmol) was introduced through a PVC pipe, and the autoclave was heated and pressurized to the desired temperature and pressure to initiate the reaction. Upon completion, the autoclave was allowed to cool to room temperature. The product was then identified using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (Agilent 6890–5973 N). The residual gas was collected and analyzed using the gas chromatograph (SP-6890). The reaction solution was supplemented with n-hexane as an internal standard and analyzed by gas chromatography (Agilent GC7890B). In the catalyst cycling test, after each catalytic reaction, the solid and liquid phases were first subjected to ultrasonic treatment and then separated by vacuum filtration. Subsequently, the solid catalyst was resuspended in a fresh solvent for the next performance test. Based on the results from chromatography and mass spectrometry (Fig. S1-S3), the main target product of the hydroformylation of isobutene was isovaleraldehyde, while a small amount of by-product, isobutane, was also generated during the reaction. Furthermore, no significant response peaks for other compounds were observed. Consequently, an analytical method for this reaction was developed: To perform quantitative calculations, the relationships of the raw materials and products was firstly clarified. The total amount of isobutene fed into the system before the reaction is denoted as na (in mmol, the same below). After the catalytic reaction was completed, unreacted isobutylene and the reaction products present in both the gas phase and the liquid phase. According to Fig. 1 , the material mainly composed of four fractions: (1) the unreacted isobutene in the liquid phase (nb); (2) the obtained isovaleraldehyde converted from isobutene with a 1:1 ratio in the liquid phase (nc); (3) the unreacted isobutene in the gas phase (nd); (4) the obtained isobutane converted from isobutene with a 1:1 ratio in the gas phase (ne). Therefore, the molar relationship between raw materials and reaction products can be expressed as follows: (5) n a = n b + n c + n d + n e The quantitative calculation of the products is carried out by integrating the data from liquid chromatography and gas chromatography analysis. The observed liquid chromatographic peaks were assigned to isobutene and isovaleraldehyde in Liquid products. Their masses were calculated based on the ratio of their peak areas to that of the internal standard (n-hexane), from which nb and nc can be obtained. The value of (nd + ne) was determined using Eq. (5). Furthermore, in the gas chromatographic analysis, the peaks of isobutene and isobutane were precisely integrated. The relative molar ratio isobutene and isobutane of (nd : ne) was determined based on their peak-area ratio. Using this ratio and the previously obtained value of (nd + ne), the individual values of nd and ne were then calculated. Therefore, the isobutene conversion (C) was calculated by: (6) C = n c + n e n a the selectivity of isovaleraldehyde (S) was calculated by: (7) S = n c n c + n e and the yield of isovaleraldehyde (Y) was calculated by: (8) Y = n c n a = C × S and the turnover number (TON) of catalyst was calculated by: (9) TON = n c n Rh = n c m Rh / M Rh 2.4 Catalyst characterization A comprehensive suite of characterization techniques was employed to assess the structural and compositional properties of the catalysts. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Smartlab-9 kW diffractometer with a Cu-Kα radiation source at 40 KV and 100 mA in the 2θ range from 5 to 60° The Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) patterns were recorded on a Rayleigh WQF-510A spectrometer with KBr as a diluting agent. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were acquired with a Hitachi S4800. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were performed on a JEOL JEM-2100F. The BET specific surface area and pore size distribution of the catalysts were measured at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 fully automatic physical adsorption instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument, with binding energies corrected relative to the C1s orbital at 284.8 eV. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was conducted using Agilent 5110 instrument, with samples dissolved and diluted in nitric acid before analysis for elemental quantification. In-situ infrared spectroscopy (In-situ FTIR) was conducted on a Bruker INVENIO-S instrument. The catalysts were initially saturated by CO and H2 (H2 : CO = 1 : 1, 1 atm) at 90 °C for 2 h. After saturation, isobutene was introduced, and spectra were collected every minute for a total duration of 10 min. 2.5 Computational methodology The exchange-related energies were calculated using the per dew Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) functional in the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) [22], and the electron core was processed by the projected augmented wave (PAW) method [23,24]. A plane wave cut-off energy of 500 eV was used to extend the wave function, together with a first-order Methfessel Paxton [25] scheme with a smear value of 0 [26]. The energy criteria for controlling the self-consistent optimization convergence [24] was 10–7. A Gaussian broadening was used for Brillouin zone integration, [27,28] optimizing the positions of ions without changing the volume and shape of the unit cell [29]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization XRD analysis was conducted to examine the crystalline structure of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1a and 1b, a broad peak was observed near 22.10°, which can be attributed to the characteristic peak of amorphous SiO2 [30]. No distinct peaks for Rh or its oxides were observed, as shown in Fig. 1a, suggesting either a high dispersion of Rh or its concentrations below the detection limit [31]. With the incorporation of Rh, the peak intensity decreased and the peak widths broadened, indicating a decline in crystallinity and a reduction in the particle size of SiO2 [30]. It can be inferred that Rh bonded with the hydroxyl group on the SiO2 surface [32]. As shown in Fig. 1b, no new diffraction peaks were detected when the W loading was below 0.8 wt %, mainly due to the low loading and high dispersion of W. As the W loading reached 1.2 wt %, new diffraction peaks appeared at 24.33°, 28.17°, 37.64°, and 49.96°, corresponding to the (110), (200), (210), and (220) crystal planes of hexagonal WO3, indicating the formation of the oxide [33,34]. Additionally, as the Rh or W content increased, the diffraction peak corresponding to SiO2 shifted to lower angles, indicating that the introduction of Rh or W led to lattice expansion. The chemical groups in x %Rh-y %WOx/SiO2 were identified by FT-IR, and the spectra are shown in Fig. 2 c and 2d Peaks around 800 cm-1 and in the range of 1010–1240 cm-1 are assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si. The peak at 965 cm-1 is attributed to the bending vibration of Si-OH groups on the surface of SiO2, while the peak at 1644 cm-1 corresponds to the bending vibration of adsorbed water molecules [32,35]. In the spectra of the x %Rh-y %WOx/SiO2 catalyst, decreases in the intensity of both the peak at 965 cm-1 and the peaks within the range of 1010–1240 cm-1 can be observed. It can be speculated that the Rh and W species interact with the Si-OH groups on the SiO2 surface, forming Si-O-M (M = Rh, W), which consumed a small amount of Si-OH and weaken the peak at 965cm-1 [30]. Simultaneously, the interaction between Si-O-M and Si-O-Si resulted in a reduction of the peak intensities within the range of 1010–1240 cm-1 [32]. These changes in the spectra confirm the successful incorporation of Rh and W onto the SiO2 surface. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution curves of the obtained catalysts are shown in Fig. S4a and Fig. S4b. The samples of SiO2, 0.2Rh/SiO2, and 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 exhibited typical type IV isotherms with an H2 hysteresis loop, indicating mesoporous structures. As shown in Fig. S3 and Table 1 , the specific surface area of SiO2 was 177.81 m2·g-1, with pore sizes primarily ranging from 26 to 30 nm. For the 0.2Rh/SiO2 and 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 samples, the introduction of Rh and W resulted in only minor variations in the specific surface area and pore sizes. It suggested that the catalysts loaded with Rh and W well preserved the mesoporous structure of the SiO2, creating favorable conditions for the subsequent adsorption and conversion of syngas and reactive olefins. The morphology of catalysts was further investigated through SEM and TEM. The images of the obtained samples are shown in Fig. 3 a-d. On micrographs of SiO2 (Fig. 3a), uniform nanoparticles with an average diameter of 20 nm can be observed, and the obtained 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 (Fig. 3b-d) largely preserved the morphology of SiO2. The HRTEM image in Fig. 2e revealed two distinct lattice fringes with d-spacing of 2.53 Å and 2.38 Å, corresponding to the (110) plane of Rh2O3 and the (210) plane of WO3, respectively, confirming the successful loading of Rh and W onto the surface of SiO2 [36]. The EDS mapping image in Fig. 2f demonstrated a uniform distribution of Rh and W. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was utilized to investigate the valence state of the catalysts. Fig. 4 b presents the high-resolution XPS spectra of Rh in the fresh 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst, revealing four distinct peaks. The peaks at 313.8 eV and 308.9 eV correspond to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Rh3+, while the peaks at 311.5 eV and 307.0 eV can be attributed to 3d5/2 and3d3/2 of Rhβ+ (0 ≤ β ≤ 1) [37,38]. The formation of Rhβ+ can be attributed to electron transfer caused by oxygen vacancies generated during the high-temperature calcination of the catalyst. This phenomenon has been reported in previous literature [15,39,40]. Fig. 4c displays the signals of W6+ 4f2/5 and W4+ 4f2/5 at 37.5 eV and 35.6 eV, respectively [41,42]. The changes in the valence states of Rh before and after catalytic reaction were further analyzed by calculating and comparing the Rhβ+/Rh3+ ratio using the area integration method [39]. As illustrated in Table 2 , the ratio of Rhβ+/Rh3+ in the 0.2Rh/SiO2 catalyst increased from 0.64 to 0.92 after the reaction, whereas in the 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst, the ratio rose from 0.71 to 1.38. It can be inferred that the introduction of W facilitated the formation of Rhβ+ during the reaction, suggesting an interaction between Rh and W. As reported in the literature, Rhβ⁺ species are more favorable for CO and olefin insertion during hydroformylation, thereby enhancing catalytic performance [37,39]. The changes in the W4+/W6+ ratio from fresh to used catalysts were also investigated. For the 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst, the W4+/W6+ ratio rose from 0.43 to 0.87 after the reaction, implying that W underwent reduction in the syngas atmosphere during the catalytic process [11,43]. Noticeably, for both the 0.2Rh/SiO2 and 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalysts, the binding energies of Rh3+, Rhβ+, W6+, and W4+ all shifted to lower values after use, suggesting an increase in electron density [37,48]. To examine thre evolution of active species during the reaction, In-situ FTIR was conducted on the 0.2Rh/SiO2 and 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalysts. The samples were initially pretreated to a flowing syngas atmosphere at 90 °C for 1 h, after which isobutene was introduced, and the infrared spectra were subsequently recorded. As shown in Fig. 5 a, four distinct peaks were observed for 0.2Rh/SiO2 prior to the introduction of olefins (0 min). The peaks at 2173 cm-1 and 2119 cm-1 can be attributed to the C = O stretching vibrations of CO physically adsorbed on Rh, while the peaks at 2086 cm-1 and 2019 cm-1 are assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of the gem‑dicarbonyl doublet CO on Rh atoms, indicating chemical adsorbed CO molecules on the catalyst surface, and Rh+(CO)2 formed [10,11,36,44]. As the duration of the in situ reaction increased, the peak of Rh+(CO)2 shifted to higher frequencies (from 2088 cm-1 to 2086 cm-1 for the Rh/SiO2 catalyst and from 2090 to 2083 cm-1 for the 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst), which was associated with a reduction of Rh, leading to a corresponding increase in electron density [10]. This finding is consistent with the results obtained from the XPS analysis. For the 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst, peaks observed in the range of 2300–2390 cm-1 are attributed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of CO2 adsorbed on the surface of Rh. A significant increase in the intensity of the peaks at 2300–2390 cm-1 at 2 min can be observed, which is due to the CO oxidation on the catalyst surface, resulting in the formation of CO₂ (WOx + CO + C4H8 → WOx-1C4H8 + CO2). The introduction of W facilitated the conversion of CO on the Rh surface, freeing active sites. These vacancies provide space for subsequent insertion of olefins and CO, thereby promoting the smooth progression of the reaction. Around 4 min into the reaction, a new peak appeared near 2040 cm-1. This peak can be attributed to the linear adsorption of CO (Rh0(CO)), indicating that a small amount of Rh⁰ was formed during the catalytic process [45]. It can be implied that the presence of W facilitated the increased of electrons on Rh, promoting the formation of lower oxidation states, and, in turn, enhancing the catalytic reaction [10,37,45]. Additionally, the appearance of carboxide (C = O) around 6 min indicated the successful formation of the target product, isovaleraldehyde. 3.2 Catalytic performance for isobutene hydroformylation An appropriate metal loading ensured both the number and optimal distribution of active sites, while avoiding catalyst deactivation caused by aggregation. The impact of Rh loading on the hydroformylation of isobutene was examined and illustrated in Fig. 6 a. The isobutene conversion initially increased and then plateaued as the Rh loading increased from 0.05 wt % to 0.3 wt %. It can be inferred that the active sites on the catalyst surface became saturated at a Rh loading of 0.2 wt %. The selectivity for isovaleraldehyde remained approximately 98 % as the Rh loading increased from 0.05 wt % to 0.30 wt %, indicating that the Rh content exerted a negligible effect on aldehyde selectivity. As shown in Fig. 6b, isobutene conversion initially increased and then declined as the W loading increased from 1.2 wt % to 2.0 wt %. The decline can be attributed to the formation of larger nanoparticles, as confirmed by XRD analysis. These larger particles hindered the formation of pair sites, reducing the overall catalytic activity. Under conditions of 90 °C, 5 MPa, and 5 h, the optimized sample, 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2, achieved an isobutene conversion of 90.58 %, aldehyde selectivity of 98.39 %, and isovaleraldehyde yield of 89.57 %. Furthermore, time-resolved studies of catalytic performance were conducted and shown in Fig. S5a. The conversion of isobutene increased with reaction time and then leveled off, indicating that the reaction approached equilibrium. The corresponding turnover numbers (TON) are presented in Fig. S5b. At 5 h, the TON reached 8936; extending the reaction to 6 h resulted in an increase of the TON by only 73, indicating that only a small additional fraction of isobutene was converted during the final hour. weighing the marginal gain against the economic cost of longer reaction times, 5 h was selected as the optimal reaction duration for this catalytic system. The reusability of heterogeneous catalysts held practical significance in industrial applications. Accordingly, the cyclic stability of 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 and 0.2Rh/SiO2 was evaluated with fresh solvent at each cycle. In each cycle, the catalyst was recovered by filtration, thoroughly washed, dried, and redeployed in fresh solvent for subsequent use. As shown in Fig. 6(c) and Table S3, the yield of isovaleraldehyde decreased from 91.71 % to 77.84 % over four successive reactions catalyzed by 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2. In contrast, under identical conditions, the tungsten-free catalyst 0.2Rh/SiO2 exhibited a significant drop in yield from 82.13 % to 12.15 %, indicating much lower stability compared to the W-modified catalyst. The solid-phase catalyst and organic phase after each catalytic reaction were collected and subjected to ICP analysis, and the content of metal elements is listed in Table S3. It can be seen from Table S3 that the Rh content of the fresh 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst was approximately 0.22 mg. After the first, second, third, and fourth catalysis, the Rh contents in the organic phases were 0.012 mg, 0.006 mg, 0.009 mg, and 0.007 mg, respectively. The total amount of Rh leached into the organic solution was 0.034 mg after four cycles of operation. The Rh content of the catalyst after the fourth cycle was approximately 0.17 mg. Rh was essentially conserved. However, some minor loss of Rh can be attributed to mechanical factors, such as wall adhesion, which occur during the separation process between the solid phase and the liquid phase. It also can be seen from Table S3 that Rh content in 0.2Rh/SiO2 decreased from 0.21 to 0.05 wt %, whereas the Rh content in 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 decreased from 0.22 to 0.17 wt % following the catalytic reaction. It is worth noting that after four cycles of reaction, the loss of W was only 0.01 wt %, indicating that W exhibits extremely high stability within the catalytic system. It can be inferred that the introduction of W constructs a pair-site catalyst, which induces a significant interaction between Rh and W. The high stability of W enhances the stability of Rh, thereby improving the stability of the catalyst during the catalytic cycles [10,11]. As shown in Table S3, The ICP analysis of the spent organic phase after the reaction showed that the leaching amount of Rh from the Rh/SiO₂ catalyst was higher than that from the Rh-WOx/SiO₂ catalyst in each reaction cycle. These findings further demonstrate that the introduction of W strengthens the interaction between Rh and the support, effectively mitigating Rh leaching into the solvent. The FT-IR spectra in Fig. 6d show that, compared to the fresh catalyst, the structure of the used catalyst exhibits no significant change, which also indicates the excellent stability of the catalyst. Moreover, to elucidate whether the leached rhodium in the organic phase possesses catalytic activity, the catalytic reaction of isobutene was conducted in the separated organic phase without the addition of fresh solid catalyst. As shown in Table S4, compared to the 90.58 % conversion of isobutene in the presence of a solid catalyst, the conversion of isobutene was only 3.84 % in the organic phase without any catalysts. It suggests that the catalytic activity of rhodium in the solution is exceedingly limited, and the entire hydroformylation process is fundamentally driven by the catalytic action of the solid-phase catalyst. It is worth noting that the degradation of catalyst performance can be attributed not only to the leaching of Rh into organic liquid but also to the weakening of the interaction between a portion of Rh and the SiO2 support. To avoid the safety risk of pressure venting under high temperature and pressure, the solid and liquid phases were separated after the system was cooled to room temperature. Since the amount of rhodium at room temperature may be different from that in solution at higher temperatures, Rh could be redeposited on the solid support at ambient temperature, which would reduce leaching. Although ultrasonic treatment was applied prior to filtration to remove Rh weakly interacting with the support surface, it remains challenging to fully prevent leaching, redeposition, and re-leaching during the cycle tests. For this portion of Rh, the interaction with SiO2 and W is likely to be weakened, resulting in a reduction in catalytic activity. Consequently, the degradation of catalyst performance can be attributed not only to the Rh content but also to the weakening of the interaction between Rh and SiO2, caused by the leaching-redeposition process of a small fraction of Rh. To compare the catalytic performance of the previously reported pair-site catalyst supported on γ-Al₂O₃ with that of SiO₂ supported catalyst in the hydroformylation of isobutene, 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3 was synthesized following the procedures described in the literature [11] and the XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 7 a. Under the same testing conditions as those used for 0.2Rh-0.8WOₓ/SiO₂, the catalytic performance of 0.2Rh-0.7WOₓ/Al₂O₃ was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 7b and Table S5, the Al₂O₃-supported catalyst only achieved an 81.72 % yield of isovaleraldehyde and a TON of 7492, which is significantly lower than that of the catalyst supported on SiO₂. The oxidation states of Rh in both fresh and used catalysts were characterized using XPS to explore the potential reasons for the discrepancy in catalytic performance. As exhibited in Fig. S6 and Table S5, for the catalyst of 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3, the ratio of Rhβ+/Rh³⁺ (0≤β≤1) in the fresh catalyst was 0.66, which increased to 0.83 after the reaction. This increase was significantly smaller than that observed for the 0.2Rh-0.8WOₓ/SiO₂ catalyst (increasing from 0.71 to 1.38), indicating that more Rh³⁺ was reduced to Rhβ⁺ in the silica-supported catalyst during the reaction. As documented in the literature, Rhβ⁺ species play a positive role in the hydroformylation process by promoting the insertion of CO and olefins [37,39]. Accordingly, the electronic properties of Rh in 0.2Rh-0.8WOₓ/SiO₂ are more favorable for catalyzing the hydroformylation of isobutene than that of 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3. Cyclic performance tests for 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 7c-d. The yield of isovaleraldehyde experienced a decline from 81.74 % to 64.09 % over the course of four cycles, corresponding to a decrease in TON from 7492 to 5877. The stability of 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al₂O₃ is comparable to that of 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO₂, with yields diminishing from 91.71 % to 77.84 % and TON values falling from 9073 to 7238. ICP results in Table S7 show that Rh loading in 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 decreased from 0.22 to 0.17 wt % over four cycles, while for 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3 declined from 0.20 to 0.14 wt %. The extent of Rh leaching during the catalytic process is also similar for both catalysts. It can be concluded that, in the hydroformylation of isobutylene to produce isopentanal, the catalyst supported on Al₂O₃ exhibits remarkable stability, albeit with lower catalytic activity compared to the catalyst supported on SiO₂. 3.3 Reaction mechanism The reaction of isobutene to isovaleraldehyde, catalyzed by the pair-site catalyst 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2, proceeds through two steps: catalyst activation and hydroformylation. We utilized density functional theory (DFT) calculations to model the catalyst activation process (Fig. 8 to Fig. 10) and presented a schematic diagram of the entire process in Fig. 11. DFT simulations revealed the electronic changes that occurred at the activated process, offering detailed insights into the surface reactions of the catalyst and the electronic properties of the active sites. Specifically, we examined the adsorption behavior of reactants, the stability of intermediates, and their interactions with the catalyst. This allowed us to identify key factors influencing catalytic efficiency and selectivity, offering theoretical guidance for optimizing catalyst design and controlling the reaction mechanism. As previously reported, the dioxo configuration (W6+(=O)2(-O)2) played a pivotal role in the reduction of W6+Ox by CO [11]. At this point, the W surface exposed two distinct oxygen sites, denoted as Oa and Ob (Fig. 8a). Based on this configuration, differential charge analysis of the catalyst was performed. As shown in Fig. S7, the differential charge distribution revealed a positive charge isosurface around Rh, while W exhibited a negative charge isosurface. Notably, the synergistic interaction between W and Rh induced a reversal in charge transfer, leading to a positive charge isosurface on W, which facilitated enhanced CO adsorption on the W surface [46–48]. Meanwhile, the electron transferred from W to Rh resulted in Rh adopting a lower oxidation state (Rhβ⁺), which aligned with the findings of the XPS analysis. In this way, the anchoring of Rh on SiO2 was also enhanced. To examine the adsorption behavior of CO on the Oa and Ob active sites, we calculated and analyzed the adsorption energies. The Oa site exhibited an energetically favorable adsorption energy of −0.38 eV, demonstrating its superior electron-accepting capability and providing an optimal coordination environment for CO. In contrast, CO adsorption on the Ob site was hindered by a repulsive interaction, which required 0.43 eV to overcome. This distinction underscores the preferential adsorption of CO on the Oa site. The projected density of states (PDOS) analysis revealed key electronic interactions underlying this behavior as shown in Fig. 8b The Oa site and CO exhibited substantial orbital overlap, with the strongest interaction localized near −7 eV. The low-energy overlap peak suggested that the bonding orbitals at the Oa site were well-optimized for strong CO adsorption [49]. These findings established the Oa site as the preferential adsorption site for CO, where it played a decisive role in promoting W reduction. This reduction, in turn, activated the catalyst, significantly enhancing its performance in hydroformylation. The reduction process on the dioxo configuration (W6+(=O)2(-O)2, as illustrated in Fig. 9 , was initiated by the preferential adsorption of CO at the Oa site, driven by its strong electron-accepting ability. Upon adsorption, CO formed a bond with the Oa site (denoted as CO* species), an exothermic process with a Gibbs free energy change of −0.45 eV. This interaction led to the formation of CO2, which was endothermic, as indicated by the Gibbs free energy change of 1.38 eV. The overall Gibbs free energy change for this process was 0.93 eV. CO2 then rapidly desorbed from the surface, further promoting the reaction. Notably, the departure of CO2 induced a significant electronic restructuring of the W surface, manifesting as a substantial increase in electron density. This enhanced electron density created an optimal environment for the subsequent adsorption of isobutene, a critical step that propels the reaction forward. This sequence of CO adsorption and reduction of W highlighted the dual role of W as both an electronic regulator and structural modulator, underscoring its pivotal contribution to the catalytic process and its exceptional efficiency. To gain deeper insight into the interaction between the CO* species and W atoms, we analyzed the PDOS and electron localization function (ELF) for CO and W before and after adsorption, as well as following CO2 desorption, as shown in Fig. 10 and Fig. S8. As depicted in Fig. 10a, the PDOS of CO showed a significant increase after adsorption (from pink to blue), with a new feature emerged near the Fermi level. This suggested the formation of a bond between the CO species and the Oa site on WOx surface. The ELF analyst further supported this, highlighting the formation of a COa bond. Following CO2 desorption, the PDOS of the CO2 species near the Fermi level decreased substantially (from blue to green), indicating that CO2, originally bonded to W, had detached from the surface, leading to the reduction in the oxidation state of WOx to WOx-1. The ELF analysis revealed the cleavage of the W-O bond during this process. As shown in Fig. 10b, the PDOS of WOx exhibited a similar trend, increasing (from pink to blue) upon CO adsorption and then decreasing (from blue to green) after CO2 desorption. Notably, the main peak gradually shifted closer to the Fermi level (blue peaks), indicating that electrons from the oxygen species, which were initially positioned above the Fermi level, were transferred to the W atom during CO adsorption. This electron transfer underscored the role of W as an electronic modulator, influencing the surface electronic environment and facilitating key catalytic processes. The mechanism of the whole catalytic reaction process is shown in Fig. 11 . The CO adsorption and activation process (steps 1–3), as discussed above, highlighted the formation of Rh-W pair-site and the increased electron density on the W surface, which enabled efficient adsorption of isobutene molecules. The subsequent hydroformylation process was similar to that reported in the literature [50]. At the Rh-W interface, isobutene transferred from W to Rh surface (steps 3–4). H2 dissociated on the catalyst surface, with one hydrogen atom forming a bridging hydride at the Rh-W interface, the other hydrogen atom was attracted to the active Rh site and a terminal hydride formed (steps 4–5) [11]. The isobutene molecule adsorbed on Rh reacted with the terminal hydride, which exhibits high reactivity due to its increased localized electron density from charge transfer from W to H, along with low steric hindrance. At this point, one carbon atom of the double bond bonded with the terminal hydrogen and activated isobutene obtained, releasing one Rh active site (steps 5–6). Efficient CO insertion and coordination happened on the vacant Rh site (steps 6–7). The activated isobutene dissociated from the Rh surface and underwent carbonylation with the coordinated CO (steps 7–8), resulting in the carbonyl intermediate (species 8). The bridging hydride between Rh and W then dissociated and transferred to the unsaturated carbon atom, forming an aldehyde group (steps 8–9). Finally, the reductive elimination step on Rh released isovaleraldehyde from the catalytic system (steps 9–10), a vacant site on Rh regenerated and a new catalytic cycle initiated. The reaction pathway also revealed a competing side reaction, hydrogenation (steps 6–10). However, as hydrogenation required higher temperatures (120–150 °C), the reaction temperature in this study (90 °C) was well below the threshold for significant hydrogenation. This ensured that the hydroformylation process maintained high selectivity for isovaleraldehyde throughout the reaction. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we successfully developed a series of Rh-WOx/SiO2 pair-site catalysts, which were comprehensively characterized through XRD, in-situ FTIR, TEM, and XPS. These catalysts exhibited superior catalytic performance in the hydroformylation of isobutene. Under the reaction conditions of 90 °C, 5 Mpa, and 5 h, the 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst achieved an isovaleraldehyde yield of 89.57 %, the 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst achieved an isovaleraldehyde yield of 89.57 %, surpassing the yields of 0.2Rh/SiO2 (81.72 %) and 0.2Rh-0.7WOx/Al2O3 (82.88 %). It also demonstrated outstanding stability, retaining 85.0 % of its initial yield after four cycles. In-situ FTIR analysis revealed the generation of CO2, primarily due to the conversion of excess CO on Rh by W during the reaction, which created sufficient vacant sites on Rh, facilitating the subsequent insertion of CO and olefin. Additionally, DFT calculations indicated that the introduction of W resulted in a partial transfer of electrons from W to Rh. The electron transfer appeared at Rh-WOx interface led to an increase in the electron density on Rh, promoting its stabilization in a lower oxidation state. This interface electronic regulation strategy enhanced the catalytic activity and selectivity for hydroformylation, providing a promising approach for future catalyst optimization and industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Hydroformylation plays a crucial role in the modern chemical industry by enabling the efficient production of aldehydes, which are essential raw materials for a wide range of chemicals. In this study, we reported a pair-site 0.2Rh-0.8WOx/SiO2 catalyst that demonstrated exceptional performance in isobutene hydroformylation. The catalyst achieved an isovaleraldehyde yield of 89.57 % (TON=8936) after 5 h of reaction at 90 °C and 5 MPa, and retained 85.0 % of its initial yield after four cycles. This performance was significantly superior to that of the catalyst prior to the introduction of W and proved more suitable for the hydroformylation reaction of isobutene compared to previously reported Al2O3-supported pair-site catalyst. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that W served as an electronic modulator in the catalytic system. The charge transfer from Rh to W enabled W to adsorb and convert excess CO on the Rh surface, thereby creating vacant active sites for the subsequent insertion of olefin and CO, ultimately enhancing the hydroformylation performance. The pair-site catalyst developed in this study exhibited remarkable improvements in both catalytic activity and stability, offering valuable guidance for catalyst design from an interface science perspective.
coredata.dc:title: Pair-Site Rh-WOx/SiO2 catalyst for hydroformylation of isobutene: An interface electronic regulation strategy to enhance catalytic efficiency
